text:
The reason people argue about the proposition of climate doom via man made global warming is very simple - not a single piece of empirical evidence exists to demonstrate the notion. Decades after climate headlines went from climate doom resultant of a coming ice age to climate doom via alleged man made global warming no repeatable experiment has been constructed to demonstrate either idea. Even the claim of observational evidence of co2 warming an area of the planet over a decade by Berkley Earth has been pulled apart for numerous reasons one of which being temps actually dropped over the period!!. 

You might think that over the decades an observational facility would have been created to replicate climate variables and how they interact. A mini earth if you will, allowing realistic manipulation of co2 levels to validate or otherwise the claim. But no, nothing of that kind exists and it is easy to see why. 

The IPCC concedes that climate is a chaotic system variables are not nailed down and neither are the myriad of interactions that dictate where the climate will go hence their conclusion that predictions with any degree accuracy are impossible. Computer Climate models are an interesting attempt at juggling what little knowledge there is but even with manipulated temp records they cannot get the warming right bar the notable exception of the russian model


Without empirical evidence and pertinent models there remains only the various predictions to gauge the validity of man made warming doom

But headline claims buttressing climate fear have all failed. Notably Kilimanjaro still has ice and snow, the Maldives have not vanished under rising seas, the polar ice caps remain and if the Manhattan highway is to be underwater as per the claims of James Hansen, the inventor of the tale, it needs to get a move on because at present rates it isn't going to happen.

In contrast robust research of over 800k yrs of ice core data irrefutably show warming precedes co2 rise NOT the other way round. Additionally  unadjusted historical temp data does not show continuous correlation between co2 and rising temps. Furthermore modern professional data bereft of manipulation (satellite and USCRN) show nothing unusual in a warming trend that started thousands of years ago after the last deglaciation. 

Doomsday via man made co2 is the greatest emperor's new clothes story of modern times future generations will wonder why the scientific method was ditched for failed computer models

I don't know...but I'll take a very educated and very experienced guess that the percentage that man creates is MINISCULE compared to the amount of Co2 stored in our atmosphere, oceans, and land mass. Once you actually STUDY the processes that release Co2 from rocks and water,....you'll see the Earth doesn't really notice man....except to smile at his arrogance. 

I did R&D in the field of composite aircraft propellers for a period of 20 years. I owned a manufacturing company that made them. I put them on everything from ultralights, to Experimental aircraft. to a giants Lockheed blimps...meant to hover 60,000 feet...weather is EVERYTHING when it comes to performance and the STUDY of weather is tertiary to my science. text: The earth is warming but there has been NO measured warming in the tropics. All they keep talking about is their models. The models did not predict that all warming would be where it is typically cooled. The only current impact of increased CO2 on the tropics is increased growth rate of plants. 85% of the earth's surface has increased leaf cover since the 80s and 70% of this is due to increased CO2. In the tropics where there is an optimal temperature and rainfall, the limiting factor to growth is CO2. Plants grow 20% faster now in the tropical rain forests than they did 30 years ago. All the terrible things they are saying in this film is based on the idea that the temperature would increase by 4C, there would be more droughts, hurricanes, floods etc. Well, these predictions have been going on for 30 years. We should  have  permanent droughts, the Maldives and half of New York should be underwater and there should be millions of climate refugees. Instead, there are a billion less people in extreme poverty, we produce 20% more food than we need and we have the least number of weather caused deaths per decade this century.

text: Too much of nearly any chemical can cause problems and imbalances.  CO2 proliferation in a closed system will kill you.  CO2 is part of a natural life cycle on our planet, thanks to green plants and photosynthesis.  The historical record shows a global temperature that correlates to levels of green house gasses in the atmosphere.  Long before human civilization there was a lot more CO2 and Methane in the atmosphere, and there was also a lot more liquid water sloshing around.  Over time and with the proliferation of green plants the atmosphere lost much of its carbon as it was sequestered into those plants and into the ground.  Please do more research.  There are tons of things that can be done in industry and infrastructure that will not only grow economies, but improve the quality of life.  We need to look past possible immediate economic hardships to developing a future that can support a continuously growing human population.  Heating the atmosphere is by far not the only issue that increased CO2 levels are causing.

text:
Ah, yes.  First it was called global warming, but because people were not seeing much evidence of unusual warming, and the climate models failed, they simply call it climate change.    What an easy way to reposition a crisis to align with what happens naturally to the earth, so you can always claim you are right.  All you need is to get the media propaganda machine going,  make big dramatic movies and select imagery to show what you want,  get the uncritical youth all riled up, and make bogus claims about what "scientists" are saying (being careful to shut out any scientists with opposing views) and you have yourself a nice little crisis you can exploit for political purposes.   Alexandria Occasio Cortez' own political manager is on record for admitting that their new green deal is more about political usurpation than the environment!

The alarmists have been so effective with their propaganda that people don't even see the evidence under their own noses.  Here in Canada we've had the coldest weather ever the last few years.  We have been consistently getting colder Springs and Falls for the 4th or 5th year in a row now.  Last Winter was very cold in Eastern Canada, with no thaw, causing huge flooding of our rivers in Spring.  This very Fall is the coldest on record, with early snows in the prairies, a cold October in the east and forecast for an unusually cold November.    I think that we are experiencing global cooling as the next ice age is upon us, just like all the climate experts and alarmists claimed in the 1970s!!  Of course, the climate alarmists always deny their opposition the ability to use actual weather phenomena, claiming things like "localized effects" etc- effectively shutting out any inconvenient facts that don't align with their narrative.  If you ask me, Canada occupies a pretty large chunk of the global real estate, so I wonder how the alarmists define "localized"?  (They do the same thing when people bring up the global warming period of the ninth century which allowed Vikings to colonize Greenland and North America - somehow the entire Northern Hemisphere is naught but a small "localized" area in which weather occurrences are not representative of the globe!  But the occurrence of a hurricane in the Carribean, now that's fit evidence for global climate change!). 

There are no mega-droughts or unusually poor harvests, nor are there more or worst hurricanes and floods than before.  Only the usual weather events we've always had.   I love how they show dramatic images of glaciers receding, but never mention how the glaciers were doing this in the 1920s and 30s (there are many dramatic images from that era showing this - all this hype is nothing new!).     What we do have are unprecedented levels of populations occupying every nook and cranny of earth, exacerbating pressures on natural resources as well as ecological niches.  Large swaths of forestlands are being cut down, concrete cities expanding all over the planet - all of these things create localized heat sinks an affect drainage patterns for water, making lands less arable.  More people are living in fragile environments and coastlines where natural weather phenomena are most keenly felt.  In my lifetime the earth's population has more than doubled - with the largest increases in vulnerable third world countries - so no wonder more people are being impacted by whatever powder the weather blows our way!

Is climate changing?  You bet - its done that for a loooong time.  Do humans impact the earth?  Sure we do, but what of it?  We always adapt and do just fine.  Taxing us and destroying our economies will not improve the lot of humans on earth, will not change the weather one iota - quite the contrary, it will make us less able to adapt.  The solution is not to propagate panic, but rather, to seek solutions to real problems, such as overpopulation, pollution, etc.  Everyone is so obsessed with carbon that you don't hear them talk about those issues.  I suspect it has to do with the fact that carbon hits at our economic base and is a more powerful tool to exploit for globalist political purposes.

text:
Nitrogen and oxygen are not greenhouse gases, which means they do not absorb infrared radiation. 

Carbon dioxide IS a greenhouse gas. It absorbs infrared radiation emitted by the Earth and reflects some of it back to the surface, acting as a sort of ‚Äòblanket‚Äô that warms the planet. That‚Äôs the greenhouse effect; it is what makes life on Earth possible.

When we burn fossil fuels (as we have been doing since the industrial revolution), we release excess CO2 into the atmosphere, which accelerates the greenhouse effect and causes the planet to warm at an increased rate. That‚Äôs called anthropogenic (human-caused) global warming.

The planet‚Äôs climate is heavily influenced by the global temperature, so when there is a change in that temperature, the climate changes as well. That‚Äôs the climate change part.

Now, the planet‚Äôs climate changes naturally. It always has and it always will. This can be due to a range of factors including increased or decreased solar activity, changes in the Earth‚Äôs orbit, changes in the Earth‚Äôs axial tilt, etc.

When the climate changes naturally, it occurs over periods of tens of thousands of years, which is plenty of time for life to adapt to the changing conditions.

Sometimes, a cataclysmic event will happen that alters the climate so drastically and rapidly that mass extinctions occur; like when a massive asteroid struck the Earth, sending an enormous cloud of dust and debris into the atmosphere which shrouded the surface and prevented sunlight from getting in, causing the planet to cool down extremely quickly. This is (most likely) what killed the dinosaurs. If there is rapid, large scale climate change, many life forms cannot adapt, and die off.

The climate change that we are seeing now, which is caused by anthropogenic global warming, is occurring at an unprecedented rate. We have seen nearly 1 degree of warming in less than 150 years. That is NOT natural. It may not sound like a lot, but, again, that kind of warming usually happens over tens of thousands of years, not hundreds. 

If we allow it to continue at this rate, life as we know it will not be able to survive, We are very finely adapted to certain environmental conditions, and we are altering those conditions.

‚ÄúThere is no observational evidence in the thousands and millions of years of data that changes in CO2 have any observable effect on weather or climate in the real world. There are no scientists in the world who can produce such observational data, and we challenge anyone reading this to send us such observational evidence from the real world or find someone who can and get them to produce it. Is the extra CO2 produced by the burning of fossil fuels driving the weather or is another factor causing the observed weather change? eg. say it was a release of heat from the earths core, due to the outer electrons in the atoms being pressed closer to the nucleus, well, who is monitoring that? So IF that were to be true, no amount of CO2 reduction is going to change the weather patterns. Regardless: This planet from the day it was created, is on a one way trip, which involves constant change. What humans do in between, is just a 'very short moment in time' and the earth will still die in millions of years time as our sun swells and boils off the atmosphere. I'd rather that we as a struggling species, focused on how we can live as long as the dinosaurs, by accepting our finite resources and making universal decisions to limit population size that sustainably supports everything on the earth. That may give us the chance to travel further out to Mars and colonise it, as our earth becomes less habitable.

text:
¬†@Arthur Giles¬† About 360 million years ago, some plants evolved the ability to produce lignin, a complex polymer that made their cellulose stems much harder and more woody. Thus, the first trees evolved. But bacteria and fungus did not immediately evolve the ability to decompose lignin, so the wood did not fully decay but became buried under sediment, eventually turning into coal. About 300 million years ago, mushrooms and other fungi developed this ability, ending the main coal-formation period of earth's history. 
At various times in the geologic past, the Earth had dense forests in low-lying wetland areas. Due to natural processes such as flooding, these forests were buried underneath soil. As more and more soil deposited over them, they were compressed. The temperature also rose as they sank deeper and deeper. As the process continued the plant matter was protected from biodegradation and oxidation, usually by mud or acidic water. This trapped the carbon in immense peat bogs that were eventually covered and deeply buried by sediments. Under high pressure and high temperature, dead vegetation was slowly converted to coal. The conversion of dead vegetation into coal is called coalification. Coalification starts with dead plant matter decaying into peat. Then over millions of years the heat and pressure of deep burial causes the loss of water, methane and carbon dioxide and an increase in the proportion of carbon. Thus first lignite (also called "brown coal"), then sub-bituminous coal, bituminous coal, and lastly anthracite (also called "hard coal" or "black coal") may be formed. 
The wide, shallow seas of the Carboniferous Period provided ideal conditions for coal formation, although coal is known from most geological periods. The exception is the coal gap in the Permian‚ÄìTriassic extinction event, where coal is rare. Coal is known from Precambrian strata, which predate land plants‚Äîthis coal is presumed to have originated from residues of algae.


You don't need a biblical miracle to make coal. All you need is millions of years of random events--as with everything else we see on this beautiful and strange planet we call Earth.

author: robert hicks

text:
‚Äã¬†@robert hicks¬†, using gravity to generate electricity means converting potential energy into kinetic energy. In other words, mass which is up has to fall down.

That's the only way to use gravity to generate electricity.

That only works until all the mass that was up has fallen down. After that, you can no longer generate electricity, until something carries the mass which is now down, back up.

For hydroelectric power, that "something" is the Sun. It evaporates water at ground level,  which (because water vapor is a lifting gas) rises to the mid-troposphere. There the water vapor condenses, and rains out, filling the reservoir behind the dam.

There ain't no free lunch. You can't generate power from nothing. Period.

If you think that isn't so, then you are as confused as the makers of this hideous video.

The models themselves are projecting future climate inaccurately because many of the most influential factors are left out and other factors like CO2 are given too much influence.

It has been argued - I feel quite successfully - that once you pass a certain threshold of CO2 in the atmosphere it's warming effects fall off a cliff. That doesn't mean that the environment will not be warmer it means that CO2 can only warm the environment by a limited amount and after we hit that limit CO2 has no effect. In more basic terms there's a saturation point like a wet rag CO2 gas can only hold on to so much infrared radiation, bigger rags hold less water in proportion to their size due to water's weight and surface tension.
Making matter much worse is the simple fact that as it stands CO2 has a tiny fraction of the impact on radiative heating compared to water vapor.

author: William Goode

text: ¬†@William Goode¬† Deforestation is of course a problem even for Vegan foods but not nearly as high as for animal foods. Both should be stopped. We should be growing in farming factories using aeroponics because that would require very little land for extremely high yields. Hydroponics is when plants roots sit in nutrient dense water instead of being watered, and it uses 80% less water than normal farming. Aeroponics is when roots hang on shelves and are periodically sprayed with nutrient dense water, which uses 50% less water than hydroponics. There's so many reasons to be using Aeroponics indoor farming factories, it would allow for literally any city to produce high quality organic food for cheap. Japan has some aero farms up already.
